lines.text: Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI, EXETER, GLOUCESTER,  WARWICK, SOMERSET, and SUFFOLK; the BISHOP OF  WINCHESTER, RICHARD PLANTAGENET, and others.  GLOUCESTER offers to put up a bill; BISHOP OF WINCHESTER snatches it, and tears it

lines.speaker: of winchester
lines.text: Comest thou with deep premeditated lines, With written pamphlets studiously devised, Humphrey of Gloucester? If thou canst accuse, Or aught intend'st to lay unto my charge, Do it without invention, suddenly; As I with sudden and extemporal speech Purpose to answer what thou canst object.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Presumptuous priest! this place commands my patience, Or thou shouldst find thou hast dishonour'd me. Think not, although in writing I preferr'd The manner of thy vile outrageous crimes, That therefore I have forged, or am not able Verbatim to rehearse the method of my pen: No, prelate; such is thy audacious wickedness, Thy lewd, pestiferous and dissentious pranks, As very infants prattle of thy pride. Thou art a most pernicious usurer, Forward by nature, enemy to peace; Lascivious, wanton, more than well beseems A man of thy profession and degree; And for thy treachery, what's more manifest? In that thou laid'st a trap to take my life, As well at London bridge as at the Tower. Beside, I fear me, if thy thoughts were sifted, The king, thy sovereign, is not quite exempt From envious malice of thy swelling heart. BISHOP

lines.speaker: of winchester
lines.text: Gloucester, I do defy thee. Lords, vouchsafe To give me hearing what I shall reply. If I were covetous, ambitious or perverse, As he will have me, how am I so poor? Or how haps it I seek not to advance Or raise myself, but keep my wonted calling? And for dissension, who preferreth peace More than I do?--except I be provoked. No, my good lords, it is not that offends; It is not that that hath incensed the duke: It is, because no one should sway but he; No one but he should be about the king; And that engenders thunder in his breast And makes him roar these accusations forth. But he shall know I am as good--

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: As good! Thou bastard of my grandfather! BISHOP

lines.speaker: of winchester
lines.text: Ay, lordly sir; for what are you, I pray, But one imperious in another's throne?

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Am I not protector, saucy priest? BISHOP

lines.speaker: of winchester
lines.text: And am not I a prelate of the church?

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Yes, as an outlaw in a castle keeps And useth it to patronage his theft. BISHOP

lines.speaker: of winchester
lines.text: Unreverent Gloster!

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Thou art reverent Touching thy spiritual function, not thy life. BISHOP

lines.speaker: of winchester
lines.text: Rome shall remedy this.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Roam thither, then.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: My lord, it were your duty to forbear.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Ay, see the bishop be not overborne.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: Methinks my lord should be religious And know the office that belongs to such.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Methinks his lordship should be humbler; it fitteth not a prelate so to plead.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: Yes, when his holy state is touch'd so near.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: State holy or unhallow'd, what of that? Is not his grace protector to the king? RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: [Aside]  Plantagenet, I see, must hold his tongue, Lest it be said 'Speak, sirrah, when you should; Must your bold verdict enter talk with lords?' Else would I have a fling at Winchester.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Uncles of Gloucester and of Winchester, The special watchmen of our English weal, I would prevail, if prayers might prevail, To join your hearts in love and amity. O, what a scandal is it to our crown, That two such noble peers as ye should jar! Believe me, lords, my tender years can tell Civil dissension is a viperous worm That gnaws the bowels of the commonwealth. A noise within, 'Down with the tawny-coats!' What tumult's this?

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: An uproar, I dare warrant, Begun through malice of the bishop's men. A noise again, 'Stones! stones!' Enter Mayor

lines.speaker: mayor
lines.text: O, my good lords, and virtuous Henry, Pity the city of London, pity us! The bishop and the Duke of Gloucester's men, Forbidden late to carry any weapon, Have fill'd their pockets full of pebble stones And banding themselves in contrary parts Do pelt so fast at one another's pate That many have their giddy brains knock'd out: Our windows are broke down in every street And we for fear compell'd to shut our shops.
Enter Serving-men, in skirmish, with bloody pates

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: We charge you, on allegiance to ourself, To hold your slaughtering hands and keep the peace. Pray, uncle Gloucester, mitigate this strife. First Serving-man Nay, if we be forbidden stones, We'll fall to it with our teeth. Second Serving-man Do what ye dare, we are as resolute.
Skirmish again

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: You of my household, leave this peevish broil And set this unaccustom'd fight aside. Third Serving-man My lord, we know your grace to be a man Just and upright; and, for your royal birth, Inferior to none but to his majesty: And ere that we will suffer such a prince, So kind a father of the commonweal, To be disgraced by an inkhorn mate, We and our wives and children all will fight And have our bodies slaughtered by thy foes. First Serving-man Ay, and the very parings of our nails Shall pitch a field when we are dead. Stay, stay, I say! And if you love me, as you say you do, Let me persuade you to forbear awhile.
Begin again

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: O, how this discord doth afflict my soul! Can you, my Lord of Winchester, behold My sighs and tears and will not once relent? Who should be pitiful, if you be not? Or who should study to prefer a peace. If holy churchmen take delight in broils?

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Yield, my lord protector; yield, Winchester; Except you mean with obstinate repulse To slay your sovereign and destroy the realm. You see what mischief and what murder too Hath been enacted through your enmity; Then be at peace except ye thirst for blood. BISHOP

lines.speaker: of winchester
lines.text: He shall submit, or I will never yield.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Compassion on the king commands me stoop; Or I would see his heart out, ere the priest Should ever get that privilege of me.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Behold, my Lord of Winchester, the duke Hath banish'd moody discontented fury, As by his smoothed brows it doth appear: Why look you still so stern and tragical?

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Here, Winchester, I offer thee my hand.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Fie, uncle Beaufort! I have heard you preach That malice was a great and grievous sin; And will not you maintain the thing you teach, But prove a chief offender in the same?

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Sweet king! the bishop hath a kindly gird. For shame, my lord of Winchester, relent! What, shall a child instruct you what to do? BISHOP

lines.speaker: of winchester
lines.text: Well, Duke of Gloucester, I will yield to thee; Love for thy love and hand for hand I give.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside]  Ay, but, I fear me, with a hollow heart.-- See here, my friends and loving countrymen, This token serveth for a flag of truce Betwixt ourselves and all our followers: So help me God, as I dissemble not! BISHOP

lines.speaker: of winchester
lines.text: [Aside]  So help me God, as I intend it not!

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: O, loving uncle, kind Duke of Gloucester, How joyful am I made by this contract! Away, my masters! trouble us no more; But join in friendship, as your lords have done. First Serving-man Content: I'll to the surgeon's. Second Serving-man And so will I. Third Serving-man And I will see what physic the tavern affords. Exeunt Serving-men, Mayor,  and c

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Accept this scroll, most gracious sovereign, Which in the right of Richard Plantagenet We do exhibit to your majesty.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Well urged, my Lord of Warwick: or sweet prince, And if your grace mark every circumstance, You have great reason to do Richard right; Especially for those occasions At Eltham Place I told your majesty.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: And those occasions, uncle, were of force: Therefore, my loving lords, our pleasure is That Richard be restored to his blood.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Let Richard be restored to his blood; So shall his father's wrongs be recompensed. BISHOP

lines.speaker: of winchester
lines.text: As will the rest, so willeth Winchester.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: If Richard will be true, not that alone But all the whole inheritance I give That doth belong unto the house of York, From whence you spring by lineal descent. RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: Thy humble servant vows obedience And humble service till the point of death.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Stoop then and set your knee against my foot; And, in reguerdon of that duty done, I gird thee with the valiant sword of York: Rise Richard, like a true Plantagenet, And rise created princely Duke of York. RICHARD

lines.speaker: plantagenet
lines.text: And so thrive Richard as thy foes may fall! And as my duty springs, so perish they That grudge one thought against your majesty!

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: Welcome, high prince, the mighty Duke of York!

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: [Aside]  Perish, base prince, ignoble Duke of York!

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Now will it best avail your majesty To cross the seas and to be crown'd in France: The presence of a king engenders love Amongst his subjects and his loyal friends, As it disanimates his enemies.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: When Gloucester says the word, King Henry goes; For friendly counsel cuts off many foes.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Your ships already are in readiness.
Sennet. Flourish. Exeunt all but EXETER

lines.speaker: exeter
lines.text: Ay, we may march in England or in France, Not seeing what is likely to ensue. This late dissension grown betwixt the peers Burns under feigned ashes of forged love And will at last break out into a flame: As fester'd members rot but by degree, Till bones and flesh and sinews fall away, So will this base and envious discord breed. And now I fear that fatal prophecy Which in the time of Henry named the Fifth Was in the mouth of every sucking babe; That Henry born at Monmouth should win all And Henry born at Windsor lose all: Which is so plain that Exeter doth wish His days may finish ere that hapless time.
Exit
